title: Overstayed visa, applied for green card through marriage need to travel international
question: I have a question about overstay. My visa expired in the end of march and i had 30 days before i had to leave the country but i got married in the beginning of march. When do they start counting the days for the 6 months overstay? do they count from the day my visa ended or after the grace period? I need to travel internationally in october which will be after the 6 months and i'm concerned that if i haven't gotten my green card by then that i wont be allowed to come back for 3 years. please help
question_tags: Green card holders and travel,Immigration,Green cards,US visas,Bankruptcy,Debt,Debt relief,Bankruptcy and debt,Marriage-based green card,Overstayed visa
answers:
Just to be on the safe side, whenever there is overstay, I recommend not travelling

Good Luck

You should consult an immigration attorney to assess the specific of your case before traveling internationally. It would be important to review your I-94, visa etc. in order to properly advise you.

However, I would advise you to wait until your green card is issued to travel. Although, you may be eligible to apply for Advance Parole it does not ensure that you will not encounter issues when trying to re-enter the U.S. or that you will be admitted.

This post is for informational purposes and does not create an attorney-client relationship.

Need more facts. Usually it is 6 months after the grace period. You can also apply for advance parole permission to leave the US while your green card application is pending. However, if you are close to the 6 month overstay period, I would not recommend travelling. As you wil be subject to the 3 year bar after 6 months of unlawful presence and need a waiver. So you should apply for your green card as soon as possible. It is best to consult an attorney to weigh your options.
